feed.title: angry-byte.com
feed.subtitle: A writing blog mainly on cybersecurity.

entry.title: How to Hack your Ex-girlfriend's Instagram Account

link.title: How to Hack your Ex-girlfriend's Instagram Account

entry.summary:
Scenario: You’ve recently broke up with your ex and has blocked you on all social media including Instagram. Now you’re looking for a way to break into her IG account and get back at her.
Well you won’t find the way to do it here. (͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

entry.title: THM Library Walkthrough
entry.summary:
The THM library room is a room created to practice SSH network service brute forcing and Python library hijacking.
Enumeration
A little after booting the machine, I start with a nmap scan.
In less than 6 seconds, I see that there are only two ports available. Using the OWASP ZAP, I visited the website.
On the website we don’t see much, however we do see the username “meliodas” and 3 oth...

entry.title: THM Anonforce Writeup
entry.summary:
Anonforce is an easy room on TryHackMe created to test password cracking skills.
Recon
Starting with a nmap scan, I see that there are two ports open which are FTP and SSH.
A more aggressive port scan reveals that that the FTP service has anonymous login enabled.
Not only that but it seems I have access to the root directory machine although not root privileges. Looking into the home di...

entry.title: TryHackMe Lazy Admin Walkthrough
entry.summary:
Lazy Admin is a an easy CTF room on TryHackMe that will test one’s enumeration and linux skills.
Recon
After deploying the machine, I did a mandatory nmap scan to see what ports are open and what network services are being used.
Here we see that there are 2 network services running on the machine. With a Firefox browser, I visited the website on port 80. Once on the site, I am greeted with...

entry.title: TryHackMe Vulnerability Capstone Writeup
entry.summary:
The THM room Vulnerability Capstone is a CTF room built to practice your vulnerability and exploit researching skills.
Recon
Once the machine has started, we do a quick mandatory nmap scan to see what network services are running on the machine.
Here we see that there are two ports open, SSH and HTTP. Using a browser, we then take a look at the website.
